title: Mozilla Wants To Split Off Its Thunderbird Email/Chat Client
summary: In November 2015, Mozilla announced plans to spin off Thunderbird as an independent project, citing competing demands on developer resources between Firefox and Thunderbird. The discussion on Hacker News revealed deep concerns about Mozilla's strategy to move Firefox from XUL (a custom cross-platform UI toolkit) to HTML/CSS/JavaScript. Commenters hotly debated whether web technologies (HTML/CSS/JS) are suitable for desktop applications, whether forking would save Thunderbird, and whether Mozilla's approach of rewriting core components was strategically sound. Many predicted Thunderbird would likely survive as a community project, while others were skeptical that volunteers could maintain such a large legacy codebase.
what_happened: Thunderbird successfully became an independent open-source project managed by the Thunderbird Council and operated by MZLA Technologies Corporation (a Mozilla Foundation subsidiary). Rather than dying, Thunderbird has thrived: the project moved to monthly releases starting in 2025, added native Microsoft Exchange support, announced Thunderbird Pro cloud services, and is now in active development with plans for iOS apps and database overhauls. Firefox proceeded with the XUL deprecation and moved to HTML-based UI starting with Firefox 57 (2017), though this did result in some feature loss as predicted. However, Firefox remained competitive. Regarding the XUL ecosystem: some users migrated to Pale Moon (a Firefox fork preserving XUL), but mainstream adoption moved toward HTML/CSS-based applications like VS Code and Atom, validating some commenters' concerns about web app bloat but proving the shift was inevitable.

most_prescient.reason: Predicted that Thunderbird would thrive as a community project and survive through open-source principles. Said 'This is what open source is about. It doesn't matter if the parent no longer wants to maintain it. As long as there is interest, the product survives.' This proved entirely accurate—Thunderbird not only survived but became more active, with community-driven development and new commercial offerings (Thunderbird Pro) that Mozilla employees never provided.

most_wrong.reason: Argued pessimistically that 'there is no such a community that will save TB after Mozilla drops it' and that open source isn't the ingredient that saves abandoned projects—you need 'drive' and 'good hackers' won't clean up 'corporate mess.' Thunderbird's community proved this wrong, maintaining the project for 10+ years and adding new features including native Exchange support and cloud services that attracted new users.

notable_aspects: The thread contains remarkably prescient discussion of web technologies taking over desktop development. Commenters like betteringred warned that rewriting Firefox in HTML would sacrifice features and performance, which partially came true. However, they were wrong that it would kill Firefox—the shift to HTML/CSS proved inevitable industry-wide. The irony: Atom and VS Code (built in HTML/Electron) became beloved despite resource-heavy arguments. The discussion also reveals a fascinating tension: Mozilla couldn't sustain Thunderbird despite it being valuable, yet a volunteer-led community could and did. Finally, there's the meta-irony of Thunderbird now moving toward web technologies (the team planned HTML+JS rewrite according to a 2015 comment), proving the XUL die-hards wrong on that front too.

bad_user.rationale: Correct on the core question: that community-driven open source can sustain abandoned projects. Thunderbird proved this spectacularly.

crististm.rationale: Wrong on the fundamental claim about Thunderbird's future. Argued community couldn't save it; community didn't just save it, it expanded it with new revenue models.

betteringred.rationale: Correctly predicted feature loss and performance concerns with HTML Firefox, but underestimated market acceptance of web-based UIs. Right on costs but missed that it would become industry standard anyway.

toyg.rationale: Provided nuanced perspective that XUL was 'lipstick on the pig' and that conventions trump correctness. Proved right that web tech would dominate. Slightly pessimistic on downsides but mostly accurate.

silon7.rationale: Predicted XUL would be forked and 'the last good XUL version will be forked.' This partially happened (Pale Moon) but didn't become a major force. Pale Moon exists but isn't where the action is.

bzbarsky.rationale: Mozilla Gecko developer who explained the real technical tradeoffs: XUL required technical debt for Gecko to support multiprocess architecture. His reasoning about engineering constraints proved sound—this was real, not just corporate drivel.

jklinger410.rationale: Critical and cynical about Mozilla's priorities, correctly identifying that Thunderbird became collateral damage. Right on the abandonment but maybe too harsh—Mozilla did help with transition.

scrollaway.rationale: Detailed technical critiques of HTML-based apps: accessibility issues, platform integration failures, bloat, battery drain. Most of these predictions materialized (Electron apps are notoriously heavy), though some got better with WebAssembly.

espadrine.rationale: Explained why XUL removal made sense: poor tooling, factorization nightmares, and HTML/CSS convergence. Predicted the switch would require investment upfront but pay dividends. This happened.
